author: AmazingDesign

description.text: A lid for a container for catching fruit flies.

Print this thing out.  Put some fruit in a cup.  Put this thing on the cup with the cones facing down.  Fruit flies go in but they don't get out.  There are no threads on this... it just sits on the cup, so don't knock it over when there are flies inside!
V3 is the thicker part... I found the older one was a bit fragile.  But the thicker one uses more filament, so I left the old part available for upload in case you want to try it.

Need More Floor Space, So I decided to make a wall mount for my guitars. So far I surprise myself again, as that I didn't think about the distance the body would be from the wall, but It's starting to look like my Ibenz Acoustic will work as well. This Link here is to my Esty Account and the Lighted Guitar Mount i am selling
https://www.etsy.com/listing/124541061/the-guitar-night-light-led-wall-mount

I printed this at 40% fill 0.27. 3 walls for the yolk
the wall mount is printed at 30% fill and 0.2 with 1 wall Print the Yolk first, since when you print the wall mount you will have to slide the yolk in right after. This will soon be adjusted to being on customizer, so you can make the pieces to fit the install. The New Yolk was extended, just because it looks better and is more reinforced.

title: Guide For Ninjaflex on printrbot simple (1405)

description.text:
*Update Jan 9, 2015
New filament guide works at faster speeds (tested at 30mm/s) and seems to work alright. I would still recommend 20mm/s, at hotter temperatures than they recommend. Place filament guide as pictured above, so it is touching (or almost touching) the G2 pulley.

First attempt at making Printrbot filament guide for Ninjaflex.
Prevents filament from tangling up.... Tolerances need to be smaller.
Still requires very slow print speeds... like 10mm/s speeds for everything... at least that's what I've successfully printed at with it so far. 20mm/s seems too fast.
Print temp 240.

comments.text: Try 15 mm/sec and increasing the flowrate in Repetier under manual settings to 150. Let me know how it works for you!
comments.author: Ransak

comments.text: You can now print faster than that.

title: Walker Wings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter broke her leg and has to use a walker. I thought I would pimp her walker with a pair of snap on wings.
These could also be added to bicycles, tricycles, scooters, etc (or your 3D printer)

The clips are sized to snap on nicely to a 1 inch (25.4 mm) OD tube. The actual ID is 23 mm which produces a nice snug fit on the 25.4 mm tube.
Scale the clips in ReplicatorG for other sizes.
Print the clips and wings
Use acetone to glue one clip to each wing making sure to orient the clip as needed.

comments.text:

description.text: I wanted a simple way to sand small pieces, and I also wanted a way to stretch a piece of sandpaper between two blocks to quickly sand large areas.  With this jig, you print spirals and cores, and you simply put the sandpaper into the jig, slide the core in, and it locks in place.  Use on its own or in a pair.

title: HO coupler box for HO wagons (as those based on OSTycoon's excellent design).

description.text:
Uses Bachmann horn hook couplers. Use either the built in pin (unreliable) or a track nail in a 1 mm hole glued in, works better.
The three files are slightly different, one is a bit higher so you can wiggle in the coupler without breaking the pin. If you decide to forgo the pin, then use the lower one so you slide in the coupler, then use the track nail to secure it in the desired position.
Use an Xacto knife first to trim the inside of the box, since you should print w/ no supports, then trim a bit the open flange.
My first design since I needed some of these. There are many experts here, I am sure that someone could do a MUCH better work than I could.
I would use the excuse that I am an electrical engineer, not a mech E, but so is OSTycoon an EE and look at the wonderful things he created !

My buddy and I had a design challenge to see which one of us could design a rocket that flew the highest. As you can see by the video. It was pretty clear who the winner was. The first rocket in the video is one i designed a long time ago and drilled out and hammered in a rocket motor http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337 :P the second rocket launched is designed by me aka rocket challenge.stl (or something like that) and the final rocket (launched twice) was my buddy gideon\'s and its part X i believe. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoNc0DGa-xk

For use with C motors only but you\\'re welcome to try your own different motors. 
Rocketchallenge.stl = print, hot glue the little cylinder to the nose cone, slip the C motor in between the fins, and hot glue the fins to the C motor but make sure to leave a gap for the nose cone to slip down on top of it. (see video/picture) 
Partx.stl = print, dremel out the rings until they fit the C motor. hot glue the rings to the notches in the fins. Glue the nose cone on top and insert the motor. Dont forget the straw (see picture).

author: 3DIdeas

title: ZSK JF08 JAF08 JB08 fusible link

description.text:
This part is a plastic fusible link in ZSK commercial embroidery machines. When the operator incorrectly sets up a design the needle can impact a hoop or other hard object. the plastic link breaks before any of the metal linkage.
This is a replacement part that can be printed to replace the plastic link. The second picture shows the pins in place in the replacement and an original link, with no binding, indicating the measurements are correct on the replacement part.

Measured from an intact part, parametric modelled in openSCAD, print and test.  
To use remove the bushings from a broken fuse link, and press into the newly printed replacement using a vice or similar to press the bushing in square to the link.

author: tfrost1980

title: Spheroid Bearing, Mounts on 1 Inch PVC Pipe

description.text:
See in action at http://youtu.be/8uS5_aBJgZs
.
Here's a spheroid bearing I designed to fit over 1" pvc pipe. The spheroid shapes helps keep the alignment, and the sleeve keeps it all together. It rolls well and appears to be able to take heavy loads.
.
I designed the tolerances so you can print all the moving parts in one print without support structures. Then print 2 of the sleeves to fit over the ends.
.
Feel free to modify to suit your purposes. Whatever you create, please cite this as the source.
.
See instructions for more info.

For best results, print with a layer height of .1mm. Do not use support structures. Combined printing time for me was approximately 12 hours.
.
Choose infill based on how much weight will be on these. I printed the one pictured with 16 percent infill, but I plan on increasing this to 60 percent for load-bearing versions.
.
  • Print SpheroidBearing.stl. This file may take a LONG time to slice.
    .
  • Print 2 copies of SpheroidBearingSleeve.stl.
    .
  • Use pliers to gently break any bearings that are sticking.
    .
  • Insert sleeves in both ends. They should stay attached by friction.
    .
  • You can try adding vegetable oil or other liquids as lubricant.
    .
  • Slide 1" pipe inside as an axle.
    .
    Alter the outside of the bearing to suit your purposes. Whatever you create, please cite it as a remix of this.

author: tfrost1980

description.text: Snap on lid for a soda can. Snaps on securely, but not quite airtight.

This is about my 4th revision of this lid, all drawn in Google Sketchup (file attached). It snaps on very securely to many brands of soda cans, but is not quite airtight. Some cans will slowly drip if turned upside down. This is designed so you snap on the front two clips first, then the clip with the lever.
Your print may fit too tight or not snap on at first, but simply take an exacto knife and scrape a bit of plastic off the clip with the lever on it until it works. Also make sure the channel is free of any debris or blobs. You may experience warping if you don't use a heated bed. Mine was printed on a a Solidoodle2 with abs and sliced with slic3r at .2mm layers and 25% infill.
The main picture was edited with paint .net just for the heck of it. It's a great free alternative to photoshop. getpaint.net

title: Printable Linear Slide Rail for Printable Unicorn Pen Plotter

description.text:
This is a printable linear slide rail for Pandelume's printable Unicorn Pen Plotter www.thingiverse.com/thing:4200. The rail takes advantage of the smooth bottom surfaces of things printed on a heated build platform. the smooth surfaces allow the slide and rail to slide easily without catching on any ridges. These pieces were printed using a MK5 plastruder and heated platform with stock MakerBot unsanded kapton. I have no idea if this will work on sanded/taped platforms.
STL and SolidWorks 2010 model files are included.

Print the rail bottom, 2 rail sides, and the slide on a heated build platform. Glue the sides (I used super glue) to the rail bottom so that the smooth bottoms of all pieces face the inside of the rail. Bolt the rail and slide into their respective places on the Unicorn. There is only one bolt hole for the rail so it might be a good idea to glue it in place to prevent rotation.
The printed rail is thicker than the metal version so you will likely have to move the servo mount forward or make the hinge parts thicker to compensate. I don\'t have a servo yet so I haven\'t been able to test it out, but it does slide nicely by hand.

comments.text: I had a hard time getting those rails attached in a usable way.  I'm not very good with free-hand glue work, and was trying to use an epoxy which didn't bind very well.
comments.author: schmarty

comments.text: Glad to hear you got it working eventually! I ended up re-gluing one side using scrap ABS dissolved in acetone. Probably the best "glue" to use I think. The alignment of the pen holder when attached to the servo is super important. It needs to be exactly aligned so that there is no torque on the slide. I had to add a couple M3 nuts to move the servo mount forward, and shimmed the servo arm pieces with washers to get it perfectly aligned. It slides very well without any lubricant.
comments.author: schmarty

comments.text: Nice work!  Using the smoothness of the unsanded kapton is a great idea.  I was thinking about how to do this but it didn't occur to me.  My only concern is wear - ABS isn't particularly abrasion resistant, so I wonder if it'll get sloppier over time.  On the other hand, you can always print a replacement.

remixed_from.author: infinityplusplus
remixed_from.title: Mk8 upgrade without cutting for REP 2

description.text: This extruder upgrade for the Replicator 2 replaces the Delrin plunger with a pinch roller. Using the spring specified in the parts list below, this pinch roller provides about 60N of force on the filament, which provides enough driving pressure on the filament, in combination with the stepper drive gear to prevent stripping. Unlike other designs, this one uses a pin style bush on which the pinch arm rotates. This provides a large lower friction surface for the pinch wheel arm to rotate on, and allows the mounting screw to be fully tightened so there is no chance of it working loose. I have extensively tested this design, which has evolved through numerous iterations, and I have also tested several different springs. With the specified spring I can hold the drive gear with my thumb and pull hard on the filament without it stripping, and its done numerous unattended prints with troublesome clear PLA filament - so I can confidently say it works.

In v7 I have added a filament guide slot to the bottom of the backing plate. I added a spring channel to hold the spring in place and stiffen the backing plate. I redesigned the arm geometry to make it pivot better - compressed and uncompressed. I altered the pin so one side now holds the base plate down against the stepper motor.   
This extruder upgrade was designed using an ACIS solid in Shark FX/ViaCAD (vc3 file included) so will behave well with Makerware, ReplicatorG and skeinforge. There are also STEP files that can be imported into other CAD programs.  
Because a few of you have asked - Paypal donations graciously accepted - whpthomas at yahoo dot com

Print and source parts, disassemble extruder, upgrade and reassemble, enjoy life 3D printing. Now that the Replicator 2 ships with an injection moulded version of this extruder upgrade, much of what I have stated below is moot. I hope the current crop of the Replicator 2 owners run into less problems than we early adopters experienced.

I have come to the considered view that the design of the Delrin plunger drive arrangement on the MakerBot Replicator 2 is defective. It uses a grub screw seated on a rubber O-ring to provide pressure on the filament to keep it in contact with the drive gear (see picture). The problem with using a rubber elastomer as a spring is that it will tend to seat-in over time, loosing some of its 'springiness' and requiring adjustment. However on the Replicator 2, adjustment of the plunger grub screw also requires the extruder unit to be partially disassembled. Now that the blower fan uses self-tapping screws, it doesn't seem like a good idea to be constantly removing and inserting those screws into plastic threads. More to the point, the amount of spring travel provided by the rubber elastomer is not sufficient to accommodate variations in filament diameter from 1.7mm to 1.8mm and maintain even drive pressure. Unfortunately some rolls of filament contain this degree of variation within the roll. In my experience, clear and white PLA are particularly troublesome. Failure of this plunger mechanism to maintain consistent drive pressure during printing leads to failed prints, wasted filament and printer downtime.  
The MakerBot website claims that "Replicator 2 has been engineered with the professional designer in mind". I am a professional product designer, and I do not feel that the Replicator 2 Delrin plunger drive arrangement, with these inherent problems, fulfils this usability objective.  
So I set about to design an upgrade that used parts which were readily available, an upgrade that could be printed reliably, and one that worked as expected.

I printed the Mk8-Upgrade-Base and Mk8-Upgrade-Arm using my 100 micron ReplicatorG profile thingiverse.com/thing:39050 with the following settings: Infill 100%
Layer Height 0.15mm
Number of shells 1
Feedrate 80 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 150 mm/s Make sure you use a PLA that prints reliably on your machine. However, some more experienced Makerbot operators are recommending printing these parts in Black PLA because black has a higher melting point. Nevertheless, solid parts printed in Black PLA are prone to warping, so I have added ear tabs to hold them down on the build plate better. Seeing these have 100% infill, its not a bad idea to print these bit leaner than you normally would by increasing the filament diameter in Print-O-Matic by +0.03mm. Once printed, ream out the holes on the arm with an M6 and M8 reamer (if you have them) or similarly sized drill bits. This will ensure the parts mate without friction. You can ream out the filament feed hole with the second smallest hex wrench provided with your Replicator 2. There is also a snap-off support on the bottom of the Base that is there to act as a bridge to support the printing of the recessed area. Carefully use a sharp knife to cut this off and use a small flat file to clean the area of any loose strands of filament. There is 0.5mm clearance here so it doesn't need to be perfect. I printed the Mk8-Upgrade-Pin using my 100 micron ReplicatorG profile with the following settings: Infill 100%
Layer Height 0.1mm
Number of shells 1
Feedrate 80 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 150 mm/s If you don't have a set of metric reamers or drill bits I recommend printing two of these Pins and use the first one with a pair of pliers to ream out the holes. Insert it into each hole separately and twist it around, the flat edge on the pin will tend to act like a reamer and clean out the hole for you. I have tested this approach just to make sure it works.

You will need a 3/8" x 1-1/8" x 0.041" compression spring. This is available from Home Depot (see photo). It is the middle sized one in the pack but check the dimensions on the pack to ensure you buy the right pack. The same spring is also available in the US at True Value hardware stores. It is also made by Century Spring Corp. The model number on a store bought packet is C-624, but on the website a similar spring has model number on 519. Phone 800-237-5225
http://www.centuryspring.com/Store/item_detail.php?StockNumber=519 The C-624 has been spotted on Amazon here
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000LNXYHC/
and on eBay
http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_nkw=C-624+spring If you live in Australia the C-624 has been sited in Bunnings Hardware Stores. Sodemann Industrial Springs has a metric spring that provides a similar 30N of force, its model number is C03600401120S.
http://www.industrial-springs.com/online-shop/search.aspx?pid=C03600401120S

623Z - 3mm ID, 10mm OD, 4mm width You can get these on ebay, some hobby shops, and small industrial part suppliers. In the US you can pick up one at your local Fastenal store. In Australia, they are available online from BilbyCNC http://www.bilbycnc.com.au This bearing has also been spotted on Amazon here
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBAYDY

You will need two M3 x 10mm counter sunk hex head screws, just like the ones Makerbot uses to hold the plunger assembly on, only shorter. If you can't get hex head, M3 phillips head countersunk screws will also do. If you can't get 10mm lengths, then an 8mm and a 12mm will suffice.

1) Unload the filament form your extruder and wait for it to cool down. Wait until the heat-sink fan stops spinning.  
2) Turn off the power to your Replicator 2.  
3) Unplug the stepper motor and unscrew the two stainless steel hex head cap screws on the front of the heat-sink fan using the second biggest hex wrench provided. This will allow the extruder stepper motor and plunger assembly to be removed.  
4) Using the second smalest hex wrench, unscrew the Delrin plunger assembly from the stepper motor. Keep one of the hex head screws for the upgrade, the remaining parts can be placed in a Ziploc bag for safe keeping.  
5) Make sure the base plate and parts all fit together - sand and file as required. Make sure that the holes in the plate and arm have been reamed so the pin can be inserted with moderate force and has a firm fit (see instructions above for details).   
6) Use the 10mm (or 8mm) counter sunk hex head screw to mount the Base plate on the stepper motor (see picture). I orientate the wiring block on the left hand side because I think having it on the top is rather unsightly.  
7) Push the bearing into the slot in the arm and use the 10mm (or 12mm) counter sunk hex head screw hold it in place.  
8) Push the pin into the pinch wheel arm, and mount it onto the base plate. Now take the long counter sunk hex head screw left over from the Delrin plunger assembly and insert it into the hole in pin and tighten until snug. I recommend that the flat edge of the pin be orientated so its facing away from the drive gear wheel (see photos) that way all of the load is spread evenly against the curved face.  
9) Compress the spring and insert it into place.  
10) Position the upgraded assembly on the back of the extruder and mate it with the two stainless steel hex head cap screws, then gradually tighten using finger pressure, making sure not to cross thread. They just need to be snug, so don't over tighten them.  
If you live in a hot tropical climate, consider making a gasket out of some card to isolate the stepper from the cooling block (see photo).

You can just use the preheat menu now if you like.  
To load, grab the extruder with your right hand and supporting it underneath with your fingers, press down on the pinch wheel arm with the tip of your thumb. This releases the pinch pressure. You should be able insert the filament right down into the extruder tube, and see it oozing out the tip.  
To unload, wait for the preheat to reach 230c, then do the same thing as above to release the pinch pressure and pull the filament out.

description.header: STILL HEARING CLICKS AND EXPERIENCING STALLS
description.text: Check your packing density in skeinforge Dimension is 0.97 ~ 1.0 then measure and update your filament diameter in Print-O-Matic, it should be 173 +/- 2. You can also download my 100 and 200 micron skeinforge profiles here: thingiverse.com/thing:39050 Finally if you are still struggling with stubborn PLA filament, try a drop of olive or canola oil on your finger, lift up the filament feed tube on your extruder and rub a light film of oil over the first 50mm ~ 100mm of filament. That should do the trick :) I had wondered at first if vegetable oil would effect the print strength, but I see no evidence of this. So I look at it like this, PLA is like high-tech cheese - if you melt cheese in a pan with oil, the oil and cheese separate, and the cheese melts and bonds together - I figure the hot PLA and vegetable oil do a similar thing - the oil ( and it is only a very small amount we are talking about) moves to the outer surface as the filament bonds due to the oils lower viscosity and the changing surface tension. From what I understand these vegetable oils only burn above 246c ~ 266c (See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoke_point), so while it may be adding some sort of a patina inside the heating chamber (much like you season a cast iron pan), it shouldn't cause any burnt deposits that might gum up the system - but be cautious, I would apply vegetable oil very very sparingly, and only when you think you need to.

If your extruder stepper motor should happen to overheat in 45 degree c summer heat, it may cause the PLA arm to soften and bend out of shape. If this happens to you, don't be alarmed there is a quick remedy. Remove the arm from the stepper motor and holding it by the bearing screw, dip it into a cup of boiling hot water for about a minute (make sure not to wet the bearing). Once soft, bend the arm back to how it should be and allow to cool, then re-install - good as new!

comments.text: Regarding the Makerbot patent - the thing one must do before getting all worked up about this is to read and understand the claims. Claim 1. it the most important. You will notice that their invention involves a cam lock, which is a separate part of the mechanism that is included in their Claim 1. The cam lock holds the sprung pinch arm open in order to make filament changes easier. This is the design they used in the Replicator 2X. I think this is substantially different to my design, and with it Makerbot makes a novel, inventive and original contribution to the art, and therefore does not infringe on my design or place any restriction on printing and using my design. So from my perspective I think it is an over-reach to claim that Makerbot patented my design - what Makerbot did was patent something that is quite distinct and different.
comments.author: whpthomas

comments.text: But.... aren't all of the other claims still trying to patent this exact design? Or an even more vague representation of this design?
comments.author: whpthomas

comments.text:
Like I said, you really need to read and understand the claims - in the MBI patent claim 1 and 14 are the important ones. For example, here is claim 1.
"An extruder assembly comprising: an extruder comprising an input opening aligned to a feedpath for a filament of build material, a chamber shaped and sized to pass the build material along the feedpath, and an orifice to discharge the build material in an extrusion;
a drive gear having a number of teeth positioned to engage the filament in the feedpath;
a bearing positioned opposite the drive gear along the feedpath;
a spring coupled to the bearing and biasing the bearing toward the drive gear with a spring force;
a lever extending from the extruder assembly to manually move the bearing against the spring force away from the feedpath;
and a locking mechanism to secure the lever in a position with the bearing moved away from and out of the feedpath."
A mechanism must include all of the elements in this claim, in order to infringe this patent. So in the case of my design, which does not have the locking mechanism - describe at the bottom of claim 1 - it does not infringe on this patent. All the subsequent claims in the patent add are in addition to claim one. Except claim 14, which simply duplicates claim one with the addition of a manual release, but once again all steps are required before the patent is infringed. So if you want to avoid infringing this patent all you have to do is leave one of the steps in claim 1 or 14 out, change one of the steps in claim 1 or 14, or add an additional step into mix.
comments.author: nhfoley

comments.text:
Agreed... but if that one line about the "locking open" feature were removed, the patent would indeed describe nothing but your design.
We can be intentionally obtuse and talk like the "locking open" feature is a revolutionary addition to the community-developed designs, but in reality it seems like an incremental improvement at best. Doesn't treating it as the feature that makes this design patentable or valuable unquestionably diminish the work of people like yourself who developed, tested, and solved a solution to a much more significant shortcoming in Makerbot's previous design? Isn't it acting in bad faith to take 80% of a great, totally open design, add another 10% to make it slightly better, and then claim ownership over that 80%+10% combo, and any future designs that might spring from that combo?
You're an inventor and designer; I have a hard time believing you wouldn't be incensed if I, as some random asshat, added a minor mechanical improvement to your design, claimed it as my own, and patented it. You'd be (justifiably) angry, I suspect, because I would have taken your open-source design and claimed an entire swath of its offspring as my own property, and because what had begun as an open-source, community effort would now be permanently tainted by the fact that a subset of all possible great designs were off-limits.
To be clear - I'm not anti-IP protection at all... I've considered plenty of my own patents - but this action sets a disturbing precedent in an industry with amazing and world-transforming potential.
comments.author: whpthomas

comments.text: the fan on the side is there to regulate the extruded filament, to cool it off as the printer head moves. you can toggle this on and off if you want a slower or faster cool. by default, it comes on when the head starts printing. as for the 40mm, the fan comes on to help regulate the extruder itself. there isnâ€™t really any temp regulator for the servo. try thisâ€¦ use a test print to determine how long it takes for the servo to heat up to the point of your â€œfailureâ€&#157;. then, let everything cool off, unload your filament, and remove the upgrade or stock plunger, whichever you are using. leave everything disconnected, run the software in â€œloadâ€&#157; mode. this should activate the servo. it has a five minute shutoff, so you may need to do this two or three times, depending on how long it took for your test print to heat up the servo. if it heats up, you probably need a new servo motor, if it doesn't overheat, I would guess that your filament is being pressed against the head too hard, causing the servo to overwork. you need to look at your  upgrade and make sure it printed with the correct dimensions. if they are okay, make sure the spring you are using is the one in the description. this could be the cause of too much tension, as could using the incorrect bearing.

Unfortunatly I have to have someone else print the parts as my printer is in bits. On a side note I noticed that some people have fitted the mod but are still having problems with slippage. I have just stripped my brand new Rep2 down in frustration and have found that the temp sender in the heater block is only lightly crimped to the thermister wire. when I pulled the wire it simply fell out of the fitting in the Heater block. I believe that the wire should be soldered into the fitting. When the head moves the wire has an air gap around it which can only be giving out an incorrect value as air in non conductive. My machine has suffered from blockage and jams since I received it and now i believe that this may be the cause, that the heater block might not be hot enough which is causing the Filament to not melt. Anyway Thanks again and I look forward to fitting your design.

comments.text: If the printed parts do not fit together with just a light cleanup, you may have a smidgen too much plastic coming out - try adding 0.03 or even 0.05 to your filament diameter in Print-O-Matic - just for these prints - that should make the extrusion a bit leaner and reduce the amount of after-print clean up involved. If you have variation in your filament diameter - go for the larger value (in this particular case) rather than the average. So In your case start with 1.80 mm and if that's too rich, try 1.82 mm

author: eboele

title: Anti backlash housing for 1/2 inch thread

description.text: I am in the midst (a slow midst) of building a CNC mill and my frugal side didn't want to fork out the cash for proper anti backlash threads/nuts. My local Bunnings store sold relatively cheap 1/2" threads and so I designed this as a cheap alternative makeshift anti backlash system. It fits quite snugly and seems to remove all the play but is not yet tested. It uses two nuts and a spring I managed to remove from an old office printer. The .skp is uploaded for modifying.

Print two - one for each side. Other requirements include the 1/2" thread with two 1/2" nuts to suit which I purchased from Bunnings [for the Aussies] (See .skp file for exact dimensions). The spring I removed from an office printer that was no longer working - was around 16mm OD. I am stilling playing around with the spring length but suffice to say, having it too long creates a bit too much tension. And lastly you will need some fixings for mounting.

comments.text: I found that for the nuts I had, I needed to lengthen the cavities for the nuts to allow them to move.  the current design kept them in place so it would not work.

comments.text: horizontal legs are 330mm, vertical legs are 812mm. Diagonal rods are 305mm from center of eyelets. Based on my previous implementation of Hex box. Follow my rule that joining mechanism should be integrated to the box structure.(rather than using a separate joint part)
.
This time, a "sliding" joint was employed so that the surface area for taking the tensional force increase. This would make the box more durable.
.
In additional, sliding mechanism also make the adding and removal of box easier.
.
Moreover, you can joining two or more boxes, like what I do in the photo, to make the structure more resist to falling.
.
Updated on 04-Oct-2015:
Added a Wall-Hang part. Not tested yet, but should work.
.
Updated on 10-Aug-2014:
Some feed back saying that they want a flat surface. So I just add one.
For a fast but barely useable box, print with 0.4mm nozzle, 2.5mm layer height.

remixed_from.author: brnrd
remixed_from.title: Ord Bot Z screw Isolator (Wobble Suppressor)

description.text:
The Hadron is a great 3D-Printer, I was one of the first user and I don't want to miss it. This is one of my improvements for the Hadron, it's derived from brnrd's thing:38534. Update 23 Jan, 2013
Going on with the Z-Wobble improvement the diameter can be reduced to 10mm. Update 27 Jan, 2013
Increased tolerance to off-center. (14x11.2mm)

• Print the parts.
    • Slicer Settings I used:
    Layer height: 0.25 mm
    Perimeters: 3
    Fill density: 0.4
    Speed: 50 mm/s
    Filament: PLA
    Nozzle diameter: 0.35 mm

  • The mounting holes in the Z-AxisBlock are meant to be tapped with M5 threads (I used a M5 screw).

  • Mount the parts according to the image. You need 4 additional M5x9mm screws.
    • Update Z-AxisBlockV2 and Z-AxisBlockV3: We don't need to tap the holes with M5 threads, instead we can use M4 screws and nuts to mount the Z-AxisBlock and have the screws well tighten.

comments.text: Note that this design as well as fma's version would have less tolerance to off-center and bent z threaded rod than my design. Also, if the z endstop should fail during the homing process, the z nut would be driven all the way down to the z coupler while it would stop just past the post on mine.

author: UXO

title: Case for Hackable Naked 7 Port USB Hub

description.text:
ModMyPi Link sell a naked 7 port USB hub, which works nicely, but I felt I needed to make a suitable case for it.
The style matches the case I am working up for my Raspberry Pi B+.
I am still refining the fit, so if you make one please let me know how well it works. (I only had a sample size of one to measure !)
I have added the OpenSCAD files, so you can make your own mods. Notes: The fit of the lid tabs into the base slots might be a bit tight at the moment, you may need to file a bit - let me know

There are two version of the lid here, one with the Raspberry Pi cutout, the other is just plain.
Two versions of the base, one with four mounting holes.
The OpenSCAD files are parametric, and have some optional features which can be commented out.
There are convenient pads on the pcb to add two red LEDs, I like the gentle Raspberry coloured glow.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a model of an electric motorcycle which is suitable for 3D printing. The model is able to rotate its wheels and its front assembly which makes the bike turn from side to side. The rendering of all the parts, laid out, shows the position that the parts where designed to be printed. I don't own a printer but the parts should require minimum support structure. Assembled Dimensions
(L) 166 mm x (W) 66 mm x (H) 92 mm Total Parts: 35 Enjoy

Fastening Technique:
All the parts clip together via pegs. This excludes the seat, foot pegs, side stand and tires that should be attached with glue. It would also be a good idea to glue the rear fender to the swing arm. Front Wheel Assembly Details:
The front wheel washers should be pushed into the front wheel pegs. The pegs must be inserted into the front fender from the inside. The peg and washer assembly can be glued onto the front fender at this stage. The front fender should then clip over the front wheel and tire assembly once the pegs and washer assembly is fastened to the front fender. Rear Wheel Assembly Details
The rear tire should be glued to the rear wheel. The rear wheel peg is then inserted into the rear wheel. The peg is then pushed through the rear fender and into the swing arm. The assembly is this pushed onto the electric motor via it's peg. Please note that there are 5 different pegs:
  • 5 body pegs
  • 2 shock pegs
  • 2 front wheel pegs
  • 1 rear wheel peg
  • 1 swing arm peg
    • The renderings of the exploded views should assist you with the assembly, otherwise let me know with any problems.

description.text:
These are cut lines of Itajime Shibori, which has been a kind of "Arimatsu Narumi Shibori", a typical Japanese tie-dying technique for 400 years. Cloth tied with wooden pieces on two sides dies in a bucket filled with dye.
Material: Magnolia (5mm height), it's better to use hard wood.

0) Download cut-line data
1) Cutting wooden plate by laser cutter
2) Folding cloth vertically bellows-folded
3) Binding folded cloth with wooden plates
4) Dyeing

It's a nice video for an introduction.

author: ArimatsuPP

description.text:
The original spiral earring was not printable on a standard Makerbot Replicator nor Ultimaker because;
  • it was too small
  • it lacked a brim so that the item got knocked off the heated build platform during printing.
  • it was oriented sideways
    • I improved it by;
  • increasing size to 7.62 the size of the original. This is the minimum size so that all the features are at least 0.4 mm in width by 0.2 mm in thickness.
  • I added brim
  • I reoriented it vertical

Print this at 30 mm/s print speed one at a time. If you print them both on the same HBP, the 2nd nozzle might knock loose one of the spirals. Carefully measure your nozzles with a dial gauge. Be sure to do all your prints that have delicate features with the lower nozzle. Nothing in the universe is perfectly level. One nozzle will always be a few hundredths of a mm lower than the other one. Use the lower nozzle.

title: Spool Holder for Printrbot Maker Edition (8mm rods)

description.text:
I created this after finding one for the simple metal, but not the maker edition. The problem was, the metal uses 12mm z-axis rods, and I needed 8mm, so I created this and wanted to share. Since it took me a few tries to get the hole diameter correct, I had 3 I could use and was able to mount 2 spools up top :) I would recommend printing 2 so 1 can block the spool from sliding off, if that is a concern.
Note: it goes on the z-axis rods 'tight', I tapped it on with a hammer. I can make one with slightly larger holes if someone likes it. Also, those are 406mm 8mm rods, which is why the spool is so high up. After I strengthen the printer I'm going 550mm rods lol.

author: xdmlaser

description.text: A working gate with a match as an axis.

This PLA oiler project was initiated as an exercise to improve my very limited Solid Works skills and as a very functional and practical accessory for my RoBo 3D printer.
It prints very well in PLA after being sliced with the Cura Engine at 25% infill and no support structure.
The oil storage / application medium is simply piece of foam or a cotton-ball. I use 100% Canola oil for lubrication.
The backside was designed with a tiny internal ridge and therefore remains open while retaining the inserted medium to facilitate easy re-oiling with just a couple drops when need.
BTW this happens to be my very first Thingiverse submission ....Enjoy!

ou may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

I found that cleaning in corners was difficult for me with the included attachments/ends. So I created this.
"small" file is 32mm on the large side (one of the standard Shop Vac sizes) and 12mm on the small side. After printing this I noticed that just scaling the output was not a good idea because this model gets pretty thin at the tip.
To fix that, i created the 'small-fixed tip' file.This one goes from 2mm think down to only 1.7mm. It is still 32mm ID to 12mm ID (inside diameter).
Photos a of the first revision. I still need to print the new 'fixed' one.

comments.text: I printed one of these up in ABS (0.8mm shell, 20% infill). It's very stiff so squeezing it doesn't open it up very much. author: ocularist

title: Adjustable coil for mediumwave (MW) DIY detector radio

description.text:
This is an adjustable coil for a mediumwave DIY detector-radio.
For most of the most popular stations in Europe you'll need about 30 turns which gives an impedance of 50 - 180 uH. Frequency range is about between 550kHz and 1100kHz. If you like this thing, you're probably interested in building this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:425768

You'll need the following parts to build the most simple form of radio - the detector:
1x printed coil housing with handle for ferrite rod
1x ferrite rod (standard type with two flat sides), length: 4 cm (1.57inch)
1x diode (germanium type) AA 112 or similar
1x ceramic capacitor 470 pF
1x crystal earpiece (very high impedance of abt. 2000 ohms)
30 m / 98 feet of 0.4 mm / AWG 26 laqued copper wire for the antenna (20 m) and ground connection (10 m).

Box for a sensor program being run in Singapore by Roland Turner, Yahi - yet another hase index. The project is a community air quality measurement initiative to test haze across Singapore.
http://rolandturner.com/yahi/mapping-pilot It uses a small sensing station that consists of a Shinyei PPD42NS/NJ dust particle counter paired to a Spark Core, (https://www.spark.io/).

The set consist of 4 files:
  • The case base - the base for attaching the sensors and spark core to.
  • The case cover - two versions of this are provided.
    • A solid version
      • A version that contains a small hole to insert the clear plug into. This clear plug shows the status of the spark core board. When the spark core connected to the Internet a led slowly 'breathes' in blue.
  • Washer - a small washer to attached the dust sensor with
  • Clear Plug - a small plug that fits into the cover to show the status sensor of the spark core board.
    The Case cover and Case holder are printed at 20% fill. Which ever colour you prefer
    Plug printed at 100# in clear (so the light shows through)
    • Assembly
    The sensors kit can be purchased from 12 Geeks (http://12geeks.com/shop/yahi-sensing-station-kit-mapping-pilot-edition-assembled-and-tested.html)
  • the sensor board slots onto the base and is affixed with the washer and a 3mm screw.
  • the spark core is held in place with a cable tie.
    It is a pretty tight fit. The base will snap into the cover.

title: Electrolux fridge bottle shelf guides replacement

description.text: This is a replacement for the Electrolux fridge bottle shelf (part n°2425182033) guides

• Long pliers (or anything that allows you to place the nuts through the tiny space)
  • 4x M3x10 screws
  • 4x M3 nuts
  • 4x M3 washers (optional)
  • InstaMorph (optional)

During the process, repeatedly place te part to get the dimensions and the hole positioning right
  • Cut the original shelf (a Dremel will do the job)
  • Drill M3 holes in the original shelf
  • Place the part and insert the screws
  • Place the washers (optional)
  • Place the nuts
  • Tighten the screws
  • Add some InstaMorph for extra rigidity (optional)

author: Cre8tive-3D

title: Flamewheel F450 APM / Pixhawk / Flight Controller Vibration Isolation Platform (earplug based)

description.text:
This is a set of objects designed for the Flamewheel F450 quad platform that provides a third level above the top plate suspended by earplugs to isolate vibrations from your flight controller. All that is required is glue and four ear plugs.
It fits smoothly over the existing top plate bolt holes (no extended bolts required, the holes are used for alignment only)
Includes optional built in GPS/Compass tower with two heights to choose from (55mm or 75mm from top plate).

Print
4x Corner Mounts
OR
3x Corner Mounts and 1x Corner mount with GPS Tower
Glue the corner mounts to the top plate ensuring they fit smoothly over the bolts provided.
Glue earplugs to each corner mount with the thick side to the bottom.
One by one twist the earplugs and push them through the holes on the flight controller top mount.

comments.text: This is ingenious. I'll be testing and moving this over to my Quad Design shortly.

I enlarged the print bed, and due to the sheer size of it, I get a lot of vibration and the aluminum extrusion frame wants to lift off my wooden base. So I very quickly drew up this 15mm aluminum extrusion bracket.

A second version of the Cesar Manrique inspired lamp. This one is easily printed on a basic reprap. It does require glueing of the 3 pieces of the shade together though. Illumination provided by a 12v GU4 bulb.
The one you see in the pictures was printed in PLA and painted with a bronzing kit.

Print the spikes, topshade and bottomshade and glue them together. Insert the bulb at this point. There is an optional bulb shade (which I printed in clear ABS), this just rests in place, it's not needed but I found the LED shining through the shade holes a bit bright. The shade and base are separated by a hollow steel tube. There is an insert piece to adapt the shade to the supporting pole (lamp adaptor), this is an interference fit with the shade and the 17mm dia steel tube that I used. If you want to use a different diameter tube you will have to tweak the SCAD for the lamp base and lamp adapter.
manrique light _ final.scad should be self explanatory and you can tweak away to your heart's content here. The important thing is when it comes to generating the stls you need to select each of the 3 components in turn in the 'component' variable at the top of the file. This SCAD file will also generate a simple base for the lamp. I just used this for assembly and testing, it's functional but not pretty.

description.text: A stand for your iPad. Works in portrait and landscape modes and with Smart Cover on or off.

I printed this with 0.8mm walls and 20% infill. This is the second iteration of my Cool Wave iPad Stand. I took the first iteration down because I had trouble slicing it in Cura. This iteration is greatly improved: 1) Uses less plastic.
2) Slices nicely. Has no non-manifold geometry - at least none that I can find.
3) Is designed to be flexible, so if the print warps (and a print this size probably will), it will bend back into shape when the iPad is placed on it. Warping was a big problem with version 1 - it had a solid base, and on my Ultimaker in PLA, with an unheated platform, it warped very slightly, but just enough to make it unstable. The "cool wave" in question is: (Cos[x ] + 1)/(x^2/60 + 1) for x, -7/Pi, 7 /Pi I plotted this in curve in Mathematica and exported it to DXF. The rest of the work was done in Bonzai3D.

comments.text: Cool
comments.author: Terrance123183

comments.text: It works with iPad 2 upwards. The width of the slot along the base is 12mm. Provided your tablet is no thicker than this, then it should work. If it is thicker, then you can always scale it up when you print it.

title: ID Badge and RSA Key Holder

description.text:
Designed for vertical ID cards with a slot to fit a lanyard through. Also has an insert for an RSA SecurID device on the backside of the ID holder.
Just slide in the ID and RSA key. It is a tight fit so they don't slip out. Fits standard ID size: 85.6mm x 53.98mm

Recommend scaling up the size of the piece by about 1 - 2%. Print the thing vertically standing up. Tested on Printrbot Simple Metal with Repetier & Slic3r:
Clear PLA filament @ 185 C, no heated bed.
Black PLA filament @ 195 C, heated bed (60C).
Print model scaled up by 2% in Repetier.
Layer size 0.15mm, no supports, no brim, no raft, default speed.

description.text: Upscaled Hot Wheels Finish Gate for use with two-lane pinewood derby

Basically printed with raft and exterior support for outside frame, inside flag and hit pieces should have probably been printed without rafting, I kept it on for extra structure...but ended up adding another 1/16" to the support structure to help this part out in future prints.  
Update - I need to swap out the STL files, but tweaked the design for the better and it ran flawlessly for about 160 races this past weekend.  We had about 3 ties that had to go to video, but the flag dropped on the winner 100% of the time...even with close calls  
Newer files are titled FinishGate2...  There is even a checkerd flag that I have two files that can be merged on the dual extruder...though I was never able to get mine to printer properly.  
I have added my messy sketchup file for those that might want to do some tweakage.

author: blex

description.text: This is the first scan we made with our new Structure Sensor 3D Scanner from Occipital. It's a scanner that attaches to an iPad and uses the same technology as the Xbox Kinect. For this scan, we used the Structure Scanner app.

Mormon Prophet Joseph Smith Jr. placed a "seer stone" into a hat to translate the Book of Mormon. For more information, see the Ensign article on this - including a picture of the brown egg-shaped seer stone that was used to translate the Book of Mormon: https://www.lds.org/ensign/2015/10/joseph-the-seer?lang=eng. This particular replica is of one of the seer stones which belonged to Joseph Smith during the Nauvoo period in the 1840's. As such, this particular stone was not used to translate the Book of Mormon, but was just another stone that Joseph Smith possessed and looks interesting. The model size matches the size of the original - approximately the size of a U.S. quarter (25mm or ~1" in this model).

Be sure to enable support structures when printing as the lower side needs support to print properly.
You may want to print a larger copy if you're interested in more detail as opposed to the original size of the stone (try 2x).

comments.text: That does not appear accurate. A photo of the stone can be found here: https://www.lds.org/ensign/2015/10/joseph-the-seer?lang=eng
comments.author: willie

comments.text: Joseph Smith had many seer stones in his possession during various times, and this is a model of only one of them. As noted in my older comment below, I acknowledge that the model of this particular stone was not the one used to translate/dictate the Book of Mormon (BoM), but instead was from the Nauvoo time period (1840's) - more than a decade after the BoM was dictated/translated.
comments.author: willie

comments.text: Thank you so very much for putting this up.  I haven't been able to find much LDS related stuff on Thingiverse. God bless.
comments.author: jjaypops

comments.text: May I ask how you know the size of the original? I have found only one photo online, and no scale given. Thanks!
comments.author: adrastos

comments.text: Yes; I got that detail from D. Michael Quinn's book "Early Mormonism and the Magic World View".  I just updated the gallery photos to include a picture from that page which was in the appendix.

comments.text: Thanks for the info! I'll have to give that one a read. I was trying to make a replica, and made it twice as big, so I'll have to redo it, but it's important that it be accurate. :)

description.text:
You'll be surprised (or at least I was) the first time you use your phone on a tripod. It's super easy to frame and focus, and the pictures come out much better than handheld. You can use a "regular" tripod, or there's a wealth of tiny ones (e.g., here , here, here, etc.) that fit on a table top; great for shooting small parts, documenting research or the steps in a project, etc. (see here, BTW, for a good tutorial on how to photograph small objects and projects.)
My printer apparently has some issues printing small threads, so I took another crack at Giufini's fantastic Galaxy S4 Tripod Mount. This one uses a 1/4-20 T-nut (e.g. here ) to provide the mate to the tripod mounting screw, providing a strong and long-lasting attachment. If you don't have one of these T-nuts in your garage parts bin, they're readily available in any hardware store.
The flats on the mount also let it work as a free-standing horizontal or vertical tabletop phone holder in a pinch.

Print the part and clean up if desired. Mine was ready to use right off the printer.
Prepare the T-nut by using pliers or a vise to bend the little teeth up flat, so there's an even flange at the base of the nut.
Glue the T-nut into the printed part. I did this by
(a) Mixing some epoxy, then waiting a bit until it was partially cured and paste-like (so it wouldn't run),
(b) Putting a small amount of the epoxy slush in the recessed rim of the hole in the part,
(c) Setting the T-nut into it, and
(d) Actually mounting the whole thing on a tripod so the force of the mounting screw provides clamping force while the glue sets, and also ensuring the alignment of the T-nut is correct. Obviously this takes some care so you don't end up gluing the mount to the tripod. (You could also do this with a spare 1/4-20 bolt if you don't want to risk your tripod!)
Once the glue sets, you're ready to shoot.

comments.author: JakeyGumballLUVScat5

comments.text: I'm happy to make a video,  but it probably won't happen for a few weeks as I'm about to head out on vacation.  The technique is pretty straight forward though...when you mix the silicon with cornstarch and paint it becomes fairly thick (like icing on a cake).  I mix it in a dixie cup and then scoop it out into each half of the mold with a popsicle stick.  I use the stick to cram it in fairly good and add a little more to each half of the mold then is required.  Then I push the two mold halves together.  If you've added enough material some should squish out on the sides of the mold.  squish it as hard as you can as this will reduce the seam.  Next let it sit for 10ish minutes.  Then I pull off one half of the mold, run a sharp knife around where the flashing meets the mold and pull it off and pull the model out of the other mold half.

comments.text: The model needs to be decimated down to have no more than 20K faces. The trickiest part is making the positive of the model completely manifold. It can't have any overlapping faces, holes in the mesh or internal structures. Unfortunately I've yet to find an automated way of doing all this, I generally end up tweaking the model by hand to make sure all the connected bits like tails are thick enough that they won't tear when de-molding. Once you have a perfect model it's fairly easy to use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31581 to make the actual mold..

description.text:
OSTycoon's awesome HO 55 ton hopper car, scaled down to N scale.   
The new version builds the whole car in OpenScad rather than just scaling the original STL. This allows a bit better control of the wall thickness which were a bit thin. Additionally there is now a version of the car with a buck in it to make it easier to fill with a load of your choice.

Print laying flat on the top of the car. The overhangs are close, but should work with out support. Don't use a raft.
I printed it in PLA on a Makerbot replicator 2.
Use with most commercial trucks (often cheap on ebay), they will just clip on the bottom with the pin. Pin should just press fit, but a drop of superglue will ensure they don't work loose.
I find that I need to print these 10 degrees hotter then I print almost everything else.

title: Dial Indicator Mount for RepRap Printer

description.text: Quickly calibrate the X, Y and Z motion of your RepRap or other 3D printer to 0.01mm accuracy with an inexpensive dial indicator and this simple mount.  No fuss, no muss.

Buy one of these inexpensive dial indicators from Harbor Freight. (They're useful for other things, too!). http://www.harborfreight.com/hand-tools/measuring-tools/1-inch-sae-metric-digital-indicator-93295.html Print the mount part. Clean up the part and drill as shown in the PDF. (Note the "R4.00" hole is an 8mm hole to fit over a RepRap carriage guide rod.) Attach the mount to the dial indicator. You'll need a 1/4" bolt and nut to mount the indicator, and a 4mm bolt and nut for the clamp end. There's a nut capture in the part so the 4mm nut will stay attached. Now you're ready to calibrate as follows (seems complicated at first but it goes really fast once you get it): Mount the assembly on you printer's 8mm X, Y, or Z guide rod in such a way that the printer carriage can compress the dial indicator when it moves. May take a few minutes of thinking. See my photo of how I did it for the Z axis, for example. Turn on the indicator. Set to mm units (normally). Use the printer control software to move the carriage little by little until it just starts to compress the dial indicator pin. Press the "zero" button on the dial indicator. Indicator reads 00.00. Use the printer control software to move the carriage a nominal 20mm (indicator has a max 1" travel, i.e., 25mm, so we use 20mm). Read the actual distance traveled on the dial indicator. If it reads 20.00mm, you're all set! If it reads some other value, you have a calibration error you may want to correct. Let's say it reads 19.85mm. Use this formula to compute the new steps/mm value: steps-mm-new = (20.00/distance-read) * steps-mm-current e.g. on my printer: steps-mm-new = (20.00/19.85) * 52.504 = 53.141 Plug this new steps/mm value into your printer firmware, recompile and reload, and repeat the above procedure to check. May take a couple of iterations to get right on. Once you get the first axis calibrated, move the dial indicator to the next axis and repeat. Sit back and marvel at your perfectly-calibrated printer!

author: sterling500

description.text:
Here is a tool to eliminate backlash form the Proxxon mf 70.
The Proxxon MF70 has just plastic Nuts and it is not possible to install
Metal ones.
One can spend a lot of money for this:
http://www.usovo.de/shop/CNC-Machines-accessories/CNC-Machine-accessories/Accessories-CNC-Machines/Proxxon-MF70CNC-accessories/Tuning-Spindle-Set-2-mm::299.html
I just cut out a hole in the Sliding Bed and mounted the
printed part.
In the printed part 2 nuts are installed an one spring.
On nut is fixed in the slot the other is just sliding in the hole.
The spring is between the two nuts.
The pressure made by the spring reduces the backlash nearly to zero.
If you did not modified the MF70 to a cnc you need two left-hand and two right hand nuts.
If you dont know how to mound it better dont do it. Its not so easy! but is a very cheap possibility to reduce backlash ;-)

This stand keeps my Apple MousePad at fingertip position on my recliner.
I like my MacBook Air when I'm running around because it is so light, and does everything an iPad can't. However, when I'm at home I plug the MacBook Air into the 50" HDMI TV and sit back in my comfortable recliner. Usually I used a lap desk for the wireless keyboard and mousepad. However, the MousePad was more comfortable when inline with the armrest, so I built this to always have the MousePad at my fingertips. It usually works pretty well as long as the cat isn't also lounging on the armrest.

• Screw the support bracket into your recliner. Both side screw and front screw versions are provided. Use what works best.
  • Attach the trackpad platform by pushing the square knob on the trackpad platform into the square hole in the support bracket from the top.
  • Rest your Apple Magic Trackpad mouse on the platform.

This is a very simple bracket to mount a phone to a Makerbot Replicator 2. It's customizable to fit any phone, and the same script can probably work for many printers as well. The included STLs (one for front mount (over the screen) or one for back mount) will work for the Galaxy Note 3, but customizing it for any other phone is trivial.
Great for filming time lapses.
I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with 10% infill, 2 shells, at 235ºC with a layer height of 0.3mm.

author: nelsondead

description.text: Who wants to be a Trillionaire?

UPDATE 2/20/2015: I really want to put an embossing of President Obama on the blank side (for obviously ironic purposes), but I can't seem to find a good mesh that can be flattened. Anyone with the skills to remix this? I can provide the original Autodesk Inventor file... There's a showdown over the US National debt ceiling about to take place, and one of the supposed methods of getting around it was this idea of a trillion dollar platinum coin. I figured that a piece of currency worth $1,000,000,000,000 should have a nice design, so I decided to make one. This current design is a "platinum" coin 3 inches in diameter, with the White House on the tail side, and TBD on the back. Note that this is not meant to be a political statement as much as it is a work of experimental art. This was an experiment to test the limits of my Replicator's ability to print surfacing embossing; in the default size, the letters on the face are extruded 0.02 in from the surface. It came out decently in default medium quality, so I'll finish this later when I have time.

Prints fairly easily when standing vertical with support. May print better at an angle, but I haven't tried that yet.  
Note, this is a work in progress, and the back face remains (mostly) empty, minus an amusing statement. I'm taking suggestions! I'd like to place a profile of President Obama, but I can't seem to find/create a mesh. :)  
Note: In case it's not obvious, this coin is not legal tender, so don't try to deposit it in your local bank.
